body.p:
I have read attentively your statement and
communication to me of the 24th Iyar from which as well as from the course of our
correspondence I have drawn in full and can well make out the character of such individu
=als Hebrew Brother Leeser! Hebrew in the course of our correspondence you had
occasion to remind me of the saying Hebrew on my reflecting thereon it struck
me rather strange that such has been the case throughout the proceedings for in that
true Lady Clarissa (whom I have never seen since) of course you are well acquainted with
her Hebrew Father, Brothers, brother in law &c Butchers Hebrew and for her having
having taken such interest and under handed work for a certain party she surely
must have had a scent Hebrew that he is as well as herself Hebrew in the same way by father,
grand father, great grand father &c although butchers in this country are closer to the
mark of imitating a gentleman's business, by their having a Desk to write upon, cheque
book, banker, and after business hour attending at meetings with a fine coat (of course
at that moment divested from the blue apron) which is not the case in Leghorn they are
literally Hebrew and in no better sphere than the common drover, here;
consequently this may in part answer the conduct of his behaviour towards yourself &
myself, for you know well Hebrew when I say myself I mean to say
that near his departure or during the treatise of the affair he approached me closer
than he ever did for 4 years he was here, appearing friendly, and open'd his mind to me
of course as his countryman & superior, (but I held all this with suspicion) nevertheless he
had the most kind behaviour & hospitality from one and all at my house; such has
been the amiable & modest Divine that he has never had the politeness I shall not
say write me a letter, but compt. to me, or my family, and I was the only one who accompanied
him 7 miles to see him off by the Train; I can only attribute such behavior chiefly to the
above reason, and than as I took no hints of what he was coming so friendly after me, and
what he wished, he expected that I should have shelter'd him under one of the great men that
Leghorn had once upon a time the poor Hebrew beginer of the present day, was quite mistaken,
I know him well also his full weight, the first rudiments of the Bible Hebrew grammar a little
it is & ? with the learned Lecturer. I could not allow him in our official certificate
but the truth and that only, as far as his competency as Hazan. With regard to E: H: L:
you could easily perceive the truth of the amiable, the other Two naturaly falls; modest to be to the contrary
Hebrew learned, after a learned man will easily find that out, what can such a judge
signify, who knows not the least in our literature Hebrew he cannot translate one verse

from the Hebrew, the little information he has picked up in from the numerous
spanish books we have a religious points as you well know, Cuzaris, Conciliator,
Hobat a Cebabot &c &c &c but chiefly on this subject one maxim will answer you all and
any difficulty you may have, much is done now Hebrew I believe he has not written any
more than the first letters to his friends Hebrew otherwise we should have had Bushels of
puffing in the chronicle of the miracles, wonders, performed by him.—I shall in my
next write to you the cause of all such Hebrew we have some here among us equaly to
yours—I hereby send you a copy of the letter sent by me to Mr. Hart
let me know your opinion about it, let me beg of you to keep it in confidence not to
make any public use of it, you are at liberty to show it to any friend. Without
the least flattery I assure you I never read any thing more powerful, striking to the
feelings, mainly, than your Introduction & your reply to the address, in the occident
April last—you drew tears from my eyes as I was in full possession of all passed.
I shall be most happy to hear from you in hopes you are doing well, and have the
laugh over them Hebrew and hope many will have their eyes open to see it, you will
candidly let me know if this is the case which I expect it to be Hebrew
wishing you heartily every prosperity, ready at your commands. Ever sincere
